We could not understand why certain days peddalows were "not available" - eg on Fridays - seems an unnecessary constraint. They were there, the attendant was present, so why can we not book these ?  Again times at lunchtime when facilities shut down ? Gave the impression of limited staff availability. AQUA MUNDA - This was one of the highlights of the site, good slides, good pools, interesting arrangement  of water flow from inside /outside. The "River Savage" was a little tame for those used to the UK wild water rapids, but otherwise all good fun. On some days, various slides appeared closed for no apparent reason - perhaps staff shortages again ? Also, given long summer evenings, closing pool around 8:30pm did seem a little early ? - why not keep open longer ? UK sites are open beyond this. Teenagers want to go at this time, so why deny this ?BEACH AREA - Very popular, and the children enjoyed a session on the "Segway" Mini-Golf also popular and enjoyable, although expensive. Some holes require a "try many times" approach, which leads to bunching and queueing around the course. Beach has hammocks, and the ability to swim in a limited area of the lake.BOWLING / BAR - Bowling alley broke on us, so 20mins of our 60 (for 25 Euro) were wasted in changing lanes - rekeying initials into another screen. Delay in getting Drinks. Some of the pool tables "out of order". So top 5 highlights would be- Position of site with weather, local attractions and accessibility from Disneyland / UK.- Lakeside Villa, views over water and general Vista- Aqua Munda - great pools, slides, and general water fun- Lake Boating - we did like the electric boats.- Bakery - great selection of breads and pastriesSo top 5 gripes would be:-- Better Restaurant Choice and value for money, better service - Better Parc Market - opening hours, choice and value.- Cleaner and better maintained central toilet facilities.- More opening times for lake facilities, and aqua munda / slides.- Villa - better TV channels, and no need to reset internet passwords every dayAll in all we enjoyed - nice to see feedback taken on board though
title: Great Lake Vista - Retaurants Disappointing
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: This is the fourth Center Parcs I have visited having been to two in the UK, one in the Netherlands and this one in France.  With a young family, my main requirement is plenty of things for them to do and this Center Parcs more than met that need.The Aqua Mundo was fantastic and the children spent many, many hours there.  Alongside the flumes, wave pool and rapids you find at all Center Parcs villages there was also a large water play house with more slides, high pressure water jets and, of course, the huge bucket that fills an empties itself over everyone every few minutes.There was also the Baluba - a large indoor soft play area - as well as an extensive outdoor play area too.The accomodation was a little different to that normally found at Center Parcs with most of the villa\'s being two storey houses.  Our villa was a three bedroom Comfort Plus and we found it to be clean, spacious and an ideal base for our 1 week stay.The only area where I have to report disappointment was with the food.  The restaurants were only open at set times, a few hours around lunch and dinner times.  If you weren\'t there at opening time, you could expect to stand in a queue for at least half an hour before sitting.  If you wanted to eat outside of the limited restaurant opening hours, your only choice was the "Mister Croc" fast food restaurant, which was anything but fast.  On one day, it was 45 minutes between the time when we joined the queue and the moment when our food arrived.  And there were only 3 people in the queue!However, I will add that we had New Years Eve dinner at the Embarcadere restaurant and that was absolutely fantastic.Overall, I would more than recommend Lac D\'Ailette to anyone with familes and young children as the large play areas are more than adequate to keep them entertained all day long.  However, you might want to take a large cool box and a selection of food and avoid the restaurants by cooking in your villa.
title: Fantastic Children\'s Play Areas
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: This was our fifth visit to centerparcs Europe but our first to a french centerparcs. We were attracted to this parc as it is the newest of the group and a show piece site. The prices were great for half term as it is not a french holiday ususally the price bracket makes this parc seem too expensive compared to the dutch and belgium sites.On the plus side the aqua mundo is the biggest and best we have seen. Loads of slides and rapids (though not as fierce as De Vossermerman!) There is a also a superb waterplayhouse which kept our 2 amused for ages. The changing rooms were very clean and everything was very smart.The children\'s playarea was also huge with outdoor slides and a range of activities. The advantage of an indoor Baluba was a bonus point too. The French were very quick with check in and although we couldn\'t access our villa until 3 we did have keyys early so no pointless queuing twice.On the negative side this site is very hilly - looks attractive but it was an uphill struggle with our 2 on bikes literally. ( Guess I have been spoilt by flat dutch sites) We went as a 2 family party  8 in total and hired a premium 4 room villa - compared to the old style villas in Holland and Belgium it was very small. The bedrooms were ok but the kitchen and living area were a joke for 8 people - had a quick look at the smaller houses and the living space seemed similar to ours! We were in a mid terrace 218 if you do go with 2 families make sure you request an end cottage as the patio space was much larger and you seemed to have more space216 /215 looked better but check on map before you book!Make sure you take all your food or at least stop at a local supermarket in Laon we did take most of our stuff but ran short of milk etc the prices in the shop on site were a joke and highly inflated \u00a33.00 for a bottle of tonic water anyone? Also everything including the shop were shut at various points in the day so make sure you note the times.One last moan we had a bad storm on the first night - not cp fault but on Tuesday all the slides and shutes apart from 1 in aqua mundo were shut - we initially put this down to debris but later on the inside single slide shut too! Off we went for lunch and returned later surely the slides and rapids would be working now! Off course they were not 2 separate lifeguards told us it was always like this on Tuesday and it was due to a lack of staff! Many people were outraged at this after all the aqua mundo is cp and when you are on a 4 day break 1 day out really counts. The official line was it was due to the storms - however this didn\'t explain why the inside slides that had been working earlier were now not - happily it was all fine by Wed.Overall we felt that although the site was beautiful and the facilities good it was spoilt by  overpricing things that were free in the other cps had to be paid for like childrens wannabe activities and resturants / shops were pricier.Would we return? probably not I would rather spend my hard earned euros at the belgium / Dutch sites!
title: ok but a bit of a rip off!
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: We stayed here for a week 29th May to 5th June and had a very enjoyable week. The park is particularly attractive, and the sun shone every day. We loved the multicoloured villa, our wasnt on the edge of the lake but did have lake views. We were pleased with the accomodation, the comfort villa for 6, suited our family of five. (although it would have been small for 6 adults). The decor was cheery - the main bedroom was decorated in shocking pink- and as we had an end villa, we had decking on both the back and the side of our villa which meant that we could catch the sun at any time of the day. The only downside was no oven and no bbq, so had to be quite creative with my cookingWe have three boys aged 9, 7 and 7. They loved the swimming complex, which was packed at the weekend, but quiet during the week, especially on the change over days. There were numerous slides and flumes and virtually no queuing. The whole swimming complex was clean and welcoming. I had read the restaurant reviews so didn\'t eat out on site. Also the shop on site was very expensive, The supermarket in the local town -Laon was half the price. Our boys did scootering and roller blading, we went on the beach, in the outdoor playgrounds, played beach volleyball  and used the football pitch to play cricket- all free. We didnt go in the indoor sports hall or play areas as the weather was so nice, we wanted to be outside. (although you couldn\'t swim in the lake)We had a partcularly nice day out in Laon, there was av intage car rally on which was interesting, lots of old Britsh cars and then a race around the streets, theere seems to be a lot goign on in Laon, probably worth doing some research before you go. We also visited Eurodisney - 1hour 40 mins drive from the site.Also, we didnt meet any other English families, we liked this, but other visitors might find this an issue. All in all, a great week.
title: Great week, the sun shone and everyone was happy
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: This is the 3rd Euro CP I have visited in the past 6 months, and in my opinion the best of the lot.  If you drive from UK ( London). It is significantly closer to the Channel ports than the Dutch parks I have visited ( Zelande & Kempervennen ). Also the motorways are quicker and less busy.  I got a good value eurotunnel crossing (\u00a365) for a midweek half term stay. The aqua mundo is very impressive. Loads of rides, short queues. My 5 year old daughter and her cousins went barmy for them. Lots of different grades of height and speed for the more timid children. The park is very clean and looks new, facilities are very good. The smaller children loved the baluba.Tips: The supermarket is expensive and has variable opening times which are much shorter than Dutch centre parcs. If I went again I would take more food with us. The car park is a fair distance from our house (448) so going out to a supermarket would have been a long round trip.Restaurants are quite expensive , mainly due to euro conversion rate. Again, taking food from the Uk or stopping at a French Supermarket would be good idea.We went on one trip off-site, to Coucy-le-Chateau-Affrique.Historic walled town with dramatic views across the Sant Gobain forest. About 30 mins drive. Worth checking out to give you a break from the flume fun.Will return to Lac D\'Ailette, but fill the car up with food and drink!
title: How many flumes can a man take ???
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: Firstly I have to say that we have been to CP\'s in Nottingham and two in Holland and this one was very different but we knew this when we booked. (Euro to \u00a3 was nearly like for like).The journey from Eurotunnel was just over 2 hours - an easy run on the motorways.We had already checked in on line and printed off the voucher; on arrival at the entrance gates we just handed in our voucher, we were given our tickets in return and just drove in.  That was by far the quickest check in of any CP.The area is very pretty and we found our villa ok - we booked a two bedroom premium which was close to the main lake, with an upstairs and downstairs.  Everything was clean enough although it smelt very fusty.  Beds were made, dishwasher tablets & a dishcloth were provided.  The car park is back in the centre and up a large hill.  You pass the bike hire on the way back and it took about an hour to get sorted - the child seats that sit on the back of the bike were free (unlike Dutch CP) and so were the locks for bikes that didn\'t have them built in.  We thought we would hire a helmet for our 4 year old but you have to buy them (\u00a311).The park in general is easy to cycle around; the beach is great, there are plenty of play areas for children/teens, a skate park, pony rides (about \u00a310 for half an hour walking round the park) but no \'farm\' that others have.  The Aqua park is great.  There are slides for everyone, plenty of rapids where we all had hours of fun, wave machine, and a toddler area.  Seating was slightly limited.  There is a cafe in there which was good.Now for the bad bit - the food.  We pre-paid for 3 nights dinner in the Marche du Monde based on previous experiences in Holland where we have had plenty of choice and value for money.  However here it was poor; limited choice: the salad bar was terrible and unappetising, the \'stews\' of beef or lamb really looked like the previous day\'s leftovers, although some were better than others.  There was a chef cooking steaks and burgers to order which was probably the freshest although on our last night it was very busy (the first time we had to queue to get in) and they did have a gammon and roasted pork on offer.  The choice really did not change every night.  The cheese were ok, but by 8.30pm you were left with scraps.  Deserts were ok, but all the same: apple tart, yogs, coconut tart and lots of different blommonges.  There were icecreams for the kids which were good.  For babies there were always baby foods freely available.The bakery was excellent - it opened 7.30am and warm bread/croissants were ready.  The supermarket did not open until 9am and they had a terrible problem with fresh milk.  Unless you got there for 9am you had no chance of getting a fresh pint.  And they only had about 50 bottles delivered for the whole park!  Some days it was semi, others full, there was no guessing what you would get.  But there were plenty of food choices in the supermarket although prices were pretty high as per norm.We did eat one night in the Italian which was good and decent service.  Pizzas started at \u00a310 each so a family of 4 would probably average \u00a345 (we only had a couple of beers).  All children under 4 ate free at all times which was good.We did visit Crocs cafe in the dome area once - service was terrible!  The information folk were very helpful and were there most times until late.  We booked our 4 year old in to the Wannabe kids club once (pre-paid \u00a37) to be a fireman and it was excellent.  It was for 2 hours although you joined them near the end to watch them with the hoses and take photos.  The Balluba indoor play area was very good.We had a huge electrical storm on our first night and some kind of freak wind storm which brought down a lot of trees and took off roof tiles and other damage.  It was quite amazing/scary and there was a lot of damage in the park and the tree climbing activity was closed & would be for the next few weeks.  But staff were out very early the next morning checking damage and made sure everyone was ok.  We were lucky but some villas had trees on them!Overall it was a good few days off (Mon to Fri).  Food really let it down and if you do not speak any French then be warned - only a limited number of staff will attempt English but we managed with basic French.  I\'m not sure we would visit again and would try Vosserman in Belgium or back to Holland but it was an enjoyable break.We did go up to Laon one morning and I would recommend the Cathedral which is amazing.  The shops/cafes are spread out and choices were limited.  Parking was easy to access at the top of the medievil town (free) and there is an information centre next to the cathedral.On the way home we went off to Vimy Ridge, the Canadian WW1 memorial and I would really recommend a visit.  Canadian students run it and there is something for all ages.  The memorial itself is HUGE and then two minutes down the road is the visitors centre and trenches for you to walk in.  There are also underground tunnels to go down with a guide.  You can see the craters and old trenches which can\'t be accessed because of the unexploded bombs.  This is just off the motorway home, head towards Vimy/Arras and it is sign posted.  Picnic area and toilets also there - its about 50 minutes onwards to Calais (and a quick shop at Sainsburys, Coquelles for great wine bargains).
title: A different type of Centerparcs
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: Did Monday to Friday half term week and it was superb.2 adults 3 teenagers and we all left very happy - could have stayed another couple of days.It was less than half the price that Longleat wanted for the same size villa. We used our tesco vouchers for the channel tunnel so a very cheap break!Villa compact but lovely - a bit close to neighbours but when the trees grow a bit it will be more private.No oven ! would rather have had an oven that a dishwasher.Just a hob and a microwave.1x bathroom, 1x shower room 1x extra toilet - no towels you hire them @ \u00a35 so take your own!Facilities excellent - Very very clean pool and changing rooms.Rapids a bit tame compared to the ones @ Le Bois and Longleat.But very good slides (about 6 slides i think?)Indoor sports hall very good.Easy to book and well used.The review that says 25 min walk to the main bit is wrong1. this parc is not as spaced out as Longleat2. It is a fairly flat parc3.Who walks @ centre parcs ??? take your bikes, hire a bike there or hire a golf buggy. They also have those kids trailers that attatch to your bike so you can pull the kids along - there is no reason to walk - all the fun is in the cycling.The toddlers stuff is fab.A fire engine takes the little ones around the parc - all the kids are dressed as fireman and they ring the bell as they go - -soooo cute.Stable with little ponies only on site and a bit of a farm with chickens and goats.The main eating drinking place is breath taking.Set at the lake it is beautiful.Lots of places to sit outside or eat outside - but dont bother with the pizza restaurant - very bland food. Also take insect repellent we got eaten alive with the forest and lake insects.My teenagers went clubbing a couple of nights and stayed out late drinking with no hassels (apart from one of them coming off their bike drunk) but hey they really enjoyed themselves.Would like to think we will be back here again nxt year.But will go for a luxury villa - only \u00a3120 more than a comfort villa well worth it.Channing family - Devon
title: fab fab fab
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: Not impressed with Centre Parcs at all - site too big, we were located a good 25 mins walk away from the activities - it would have been worth the extra to pay and specify the cottage you want nearer to the activities.  The cottage we had was a premier one but wasn\'t anything special although the beds were comfortable it was still very basic.  The activities were all listed in French and were very difficult to make end nor tale of and the staff were unhelpful unless you spoke fluent French - no bilingual staff there and there was a lot of English there as it is the school holidays in the UK.  Service in the supermarket and food court in the pool area were terrible - only one person serving at any one time and the prices were very expensive for the activities and drinks.  Food in the italian restaurant wasn\'t good - for 2 pizzas, a spaghetti bolognaise and a kids pizza and one round of drinks was not worth \u00a364.00.  Not our kind of holiday at all - we won\'t be going back.  We prefer something more luxurious and relaxing.
title: Stay at Home and save your money!
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: This is the 7th different Center Parcs we have visited, as the newest it should be the best but it isn\'t. The parc is situated on the Northern side of a lake. The terrain is undulating and easy to cycle, except from reception and the carpark from which there is a short steep down hill. The best about the parc is the Aqua Mundo which is the best that any center parcs has to offer, with 5 flumes of which two are dark, plus 4 slides. There is the savage river (although more gentle than at other parcs) and a very long lazy river plus slides at the pre-teen Water Mill. There is a very good large sandy beach from which limited swimming is permitted. There are few water sports with no sailing or wind-surfing.Most of the villas are two storey, this means they are closer together than at other parcs and with less trees about not very private. You can see onto many of your neighbours balconies/decking and also the same of many you go past. The water side villas are best with those at the end having more balcony space. Try to avoid inland villas in the 700 to 900 range they appear to lose then sun quite early and are poorly situated. We had a 3 bed premier villa for four of use, I tihnk six would have found it quite cramped, there is far less storage space for clothes than in villas at other parcs. One room has no wardrobe. The kitchen is pratical but limited, there is a very large fridge, cooking is restricted like all European Center Parcs to microwave and hob, so you have too be a bit inventive as to what you can cook. Also the inventory isn\'t balanced to british tastes. The sporting facilites are poor compared to other parcs, and remember parcs in europe are less well served than those in the UK anyway. The sports hall is just a large sweaty hanger. The main restaurant shops area is impersonal and lacks any ambience and is not as nice as other parcs. Also there is less choice, in particular we missed a sports bar where you can get a late night snack, its either a sit down meal or nothing. We\'d have also liked an American Style Diner that many other parcs have. We like Center Parcs and will still use them, but won\'t be returning to this parc.
title: Not the best Ceter Parcs
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: I\'m not sure what I make of this place! It\'s the 6th Center Parcs site we\'ve visited and is very different.It\'s a more quality environment and is not in the semi-camping tradition of CentreParcs.  I\'m not sure about the environmental credentials either. It appears to be a bit of an eyesore - a transplanted seaside resort in the middle of the countryside. Its more like Disney\'s Newport Beach Hotel than the average CentreParcs resort. Maybe the owners, Pierre et Vacances, have influenced the design - its very much like some of their beach resorts. The positives are that the cottages are very comfortable and facilities are generally good. Cycles were well maintained and I easily found one to suit me  - unlike Holland, where sizing accommodates the freakishly tall Dutch! The traffic free principle was well-maintained and the beach area and restaurants along the lake were very pleasant.Overall the Aquamundo is probably the best I\'ve been too although there are better rapids and slides elsewhere. There were a lot of negatives though.  The cottages are not as isolated and you are more likely to be overlooked than usual. There were no logs for sale for cottage fires. I appreciate this is environmentally good but it felt less cozy in the evenings. There is only one English language channel (CNN). That\'s probably no longer good enough at the price. Cyclng out of the site is not easy (although, admittedly, Holland is a very different place). In view of the huge investment Centre Parcs coudl have funded some local road improvements to make it easier to cycle safely to nearby sites such as the ruined Cistertian Abbey about 5 miles away.The sports hall is basic but OK and at least equipment was new. Using your own could save some money but my son was particularly disappointed at the lack of a football tournament.Shops and restaurants were shut too much. They opened late, shut at lunchtime and closed early. Its supposed to be a holiday park. The facilities should be open whenever the customers need them. Local culture is just going to have to change to accommodate this fact of life.Restaurants were expensive and offered poor value for money. We were happy with snack service from the bowling alley but service in the Pancake House was laughable. We waited 30 mins for a simple crepe. They compensated for the wait by offering free drinks and then overcharged me on the bill! We gave them a second chance later in the week but after waiting 10 mins for any attention from staff we walked out.The market buffet restaurant was also poor value. 20 Euros each. No ambience and very mediocre buffet food. What\'s all this about French cuisine being the best in the world? It certainly wasn\'t here.Despite everything, it\'s a high quality site with great cottages and the facilities for a relaxing few days. Even so, at the price, I\'m not sure we\'d choose it over other alternatives next year.
title: Center Parcs meets Newport Bay!
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: We (my husband, 5 and 6 years old girls and myself) have just returned home from a midweek break here and would definatley return. We are avid Center Parcs Sherwood users and took the plunge to stray simply due to the huge price difference...was much cheaper for the accomodation in France during the half term. Having said that, we did find the prices of meals out and some activities to be rather steep, the Euro not assisting in this of course. For example it costs us approximately 70 euros plus for a buffet evening meal and a large Stella was just shy of 5 Euros a time - however we were on our hols and would not let this put us off returning.The pool was fantastic - many many slides to enjoy as a family and the different childrens area were excellent and very enjoyable. The resort was fully booked and yet we never had to queue for too long and never had trouble finding a lounger round the pool. It was a saving grace due to the weather being none too pretty most of the time.The staff were very accomodating. We did not have many problems communicating despite our embarassingly limited French....we found that so long as we were polte, they were helpful were possible. The only downside, langage-wise, was that none of the information leaflets or welcome brochures/activity brochures were in English and we found it a bit difficult to know what to do/where to go.Service was fast, friendly and efficient everywhere we went which was a real bonus.Accomodation was clean, very well equipped (we had a 2 bed comfort villa) and very inviting. The setting and colour of the well kept buildings really cheered us up as we biked round on the rainy days.The childrens play and adventure areas where of a very high standard, very safe and clean and varied.Our 2 little ones decided to go to 2 kids clubs. We were concerned they may be uncomfy should the language barrier be a problem but staff at the information centre advised us which ones would be best for them. They attended a Circus one and a Models one. I have to say it was the most enjoyable kids club they have ever been too. The interaction was fantastic and on each occassion they performed a show for the parents, showing is what they had learned...very worthwhile and lots of fun for them and for us.The mini disco was not just a dj playing kids music, it was fully interactive with the entertainment team and again we could not knock them at all...our children were thrilled and relaxed kids means relaxed parents!There was not the selection of activities to choose from like we were used to at Sherwood and we did find that 5 days was enough for us in that respect but I imagine if we had been luckier with the weather then we would have been able to take more advantage of the beautiful surroundings that the park is set in and laze on the beach perhaps.
title: Happy kids = happy parents ;)
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: Visited here in April with my husband and 2 children (11 and 14).  Whilst not huge fans of center parcs, we were tempted by the new accommodation and facilities.  lIt\'s quicker to get to that the Center Parcs in Normandy so seemed ideal for a quick break.  It looks exactly as it does on the website - very colourful and all the houses are much more obvious that at many of Center Parcs other vllages where the chalets are hidden amongst trees.  On first impressions it was a bit like a very coourful Barretts housing estate!  The trees were mostly deciduous so pretty bare in April.  In the summer it\'s probably a different picture altogether.The good things....Nice, new accommodation....we had three (small) very functional and comfortable bedrooms, two bathrooms and decent sized living room with small but adequate kitchen.  We  chose a premier village to get a villa directly on the lake.   In the summer it would have been fabulous.Considering the number of properties - my guess is up to 900, it was incredibly quiet - and I think it was fairly full to capacity.  The pool area was great - fabulous lazy river going outside and leading to an outside pool and lots of water shutes and slides.  I can only compare to Elveden and du Bois and it was much bigger/better - the kids loved it.The atmosphere was very relaxed - mosly Belguian and french - Hardly any English. (I heard 3 other english families in 5 days!)There was no problem in booking activites - unlike in England.  We tended to book bowling at 11ish in the morning and easily got 5pm, 6pm or 7pm slots.The restaurants looked good - but with the Euro at 1.22, expensive.  We didn\'t feel like paying \u00a311 each for pizza!The not so good.....Most notably, the sports facilities.  A huge airport type hanger houses the badminton, indoor tennis, table tennis area.  Whilst from the outside it looks promising, never have I see such untidy, dreary and generally scruffy facilities anywhere.  I guess, our feelings were generally shared as when we looked in on these once evening at 6pm, no one was using them!  Really, there would have been no pleasure in playing anything in this hall - absolutely disgraceful, yet great potential.If you like cycling, then don\'t expect to be able to do so on flat ground.  The village is set on a fairly undulating site, so cycling can be quite hard work in places.  Also, to get out of the village, you need to head upwards, so again, no so relaxing as some of the other villages!Would I go back?   Possibly . The accommodation really is very good, as is the pool.  However, there aren\'t many places of note to visit (although Reims is worth a visit and is less than 1 hour away).  The area is generally typical of northern France - loads of trees and fields, small villages that appear to be uninhabited and rather grey skies.  For a 4 or five day break with children, when weather can\'t be guaranteed though I\'d rate it as a good choice.
title: Great pool, great houses, awful sports facilities
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: Journey time from Calais takes approximately 2-3 hours and paying 30 euros in motorway toll charges each way. For those on a budget, one can also use the A roads which is more interesting passing numerous World War I cemeteries in the french countryside. Check in was simple, you get the key upon arrival in your car at front gate, unlike those encountered in Holland where there is a mad rush to queue to check in at reception and having to wait for long periods. CP have got their act together here. Our 3 nights accomodation cost 340 euros for  a confort villa which was nicely furnished and still looked  relatively new .  Villa 643 consisted of lounge/diner with fully  fitty kitchen equipped with dishwasher, hob, microwave and fridge freezer, ample electric radiators with underfloor heating in lounge.   Upstairs consisted of 2 bedrrooms with bathroom equipped with shower over.  There was a verandah  with sun loungers but not used at this time of year.Very well equipped Aqua Mundo, numerous water slides, wild water rapids, large tree play area for kids and wave pool. Regular evening entertainment with live band, and  for kids can enjoy the indoor play area called Baluba,  ten pin bowling and video games.   Numerous restuarants located within but the food did not look very appertising.    The sports hall is very plain and basic.  Bike hire is 5 euros per day for kids under 12.   All in all, a great resort to take kids for a short break. On the negative side, the landscaping has yet to be fully established.  There is no Satellite channels as found in other Center Parcs  Holland, only CNN news channel is available in english. Laon is a short 20 minutes drive, looks impressive from a distance as the city is perched on a hill but locality near the Cathedral is very drabby, with lots of shops closed down.  Reims is about 50 minutes drive, a visit to one of the champagne cellars is recommended,  also note that buying champagne is much cheaper at these premises than at the wine shops in Calais.
title: newly designed accomodation  a breath of fresh air
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)

review: We stayed at this new Center Parcs 22nd to 26th October 2007. It is their newest village, apparently it opened 28th September 2007.It is near Laon, the nearest major town would be Reims. It\u2019s about 2\u00bd hours from Calais ferry terminal. The last section, across country from Jct 13 of the A26, is deceptive and it\u2019ll take you 30 mins to reach the park from the motorway \u2013 the road signs are good from nr Laon.The village has a new and different look about it, all of the cottages are in a kind of New England weatherboard style; each finished in a different colour, and looking like a Dulux advert!The park is so new that it\u2019ll take a little time for all the earthworks and the planting to bed-in and begin to flourish, but you can see that it is going to develop into something really quite special.We had a great week. We rented a \'VIP Style\' cottage, and that accommodation was fabulous; two bedrooms, three bathrooms, body-jet shower, Jacuzzi bath, sauna with min wet-room shower area, microwave, dishwasher, all the kitchen appliances you could wish for, modern d\u00e9cor, daily maid service & fresh towels, great outside veranda and seating, and great views across the lake.Our cottage was fabulous, and very good value. Absolutely cannot fault it. We would return purely for this accommodation!The setting around the lake and in the woods is really very nice. The centre buildings open out onto lakeside boardwalk and the restaurants will provide a fabulous lakeside setting next year when the weather warms up.The main atrium and restaurant areas are quite spectacular when you first walk in.Probably the best pool that we have come across at CP; loads of slides for the kids, and a large tree house style water play area with a huge water barrel that tips and empties every few minutes.They have a huge variety of all new bicycles to choose from \u2013 something for all ages. They even have specials like go-kart style leaning pedal cars, right up to electric golf buggies for hire.I\u2019ve posted a few photos, they should give you a good impression of how it isA really beautiful setting, we\u2019ll be back \u2026\u2026A few negatives:Possibly a lack of seating areas within the Aqua Mundo pool dome; it was quiet when we were there, but I am sure that when it gets busy there will not be enough room.Slippery floors in the pool area \u2013 hard to believe that after al these years and with all their experience Center parcs have failed to get the floor right (I can remember all the pool area flooring at Elveden in the UK being over-tiled many years ago, before the fire!).Disappointing that the Lagoon Bar was not finished and opened whilst we were there \u2013 and a shame that they did not bother to put up any kind of notice nor provide any facilities from that bar \u2013 coke/coffee and snacks by the pool are all part of the CP experience. No Aqua Sana area. No squash courts. The Sports Hall is probably the most basic we have seen; an aircraft hanger with tarmac surfaced courts.No English newspapers.Only one English-speaking TV channel in the cottage (CNN \u2013 all USA News).Bread roll delivery to the cottage was not included, as it is in NL.The lack of serving staff in the restaurants and the Reception areas. The fast food bar \u201cCroc\u201d really suffered from this \u2013 it just was not actually fast food at all \u2013 there was usually a great queue of frustrated customers \u2013 my sons complained of tepid burgers and over-cooked chips. The pizza restaurant was similarly under-staffed; 2 hours for 2 courses; the staff were very stressed and very apologetic.The Menus were generally not that special; we tried three restaurants. The ambience was great, but you had to study the menu for something you fancied (about on a par with Beefeater / Harvester).We missed the Chez Pierre type restaurant that CP would normally have in the main dome square; the coffee was not great, and the only snack available was various ice cream desserts!! (Normally, in the UK and NL, there\u2019s a really tempting range of cakes, apple pie, gateaux, etc).We were there for four days, the free internet connection in the main dome area was not available for two of those days.
title: First review of great new Center Parcs in France ....
price_range: $ (Based on Average Nightly Rates for a Standard Room from our Partners)
